body: This is a known bug where pressing the Enter key after renaming a scene reverts the name. If you click somewhere else in OBS to deselect the name instead of pressing Enter, the new name will stick.
Ok, thanks.  Didn’t know this was a known bug.

We can keep this open, I don't think there's an issue open for this already.

In the future, though, please be sure to completely fill out the issue template.

The solution is to press Command + Enter rather than just Enter.

I assume that pressing enter starts a new renaming 'session' each time, this doesn't happen on Windows because you use F2 to rename then enter to accept.

The root cause of this bug appears to be in window-basic-main.cpp#L315 where the UI element has “Qt::Key_Return” added as a shortcut. This appears to cause the Edit to be called again when the user hits “Enter” once more. This explanation is incomplete as it doesn’t provide for a reason for the slightly different behaviors between the Source and Scene.

Commenting out the lines allows it to work as expected. Investigation details are on the livedebug.dev page for [this issue](https://www.livedebug.dev/obs-studio-3044/README.html).  Have a pending discussion on #development on discord to understand the next steps to resolve.  

Commenting out the lines above remove the <Return> to edit functionality, but when editing through the context menu allows the edit to be saved with "enter".

I'm creating a PR request to resolve this.  I couldn't find any references in the [macOS User Interface Guidelines](https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/macos/overview/themes/) covering the default edit behaviors.  Most of the Apple interfaces do not allow editing by hitting enter.  You either select the item and hit the gear icon or right click to rename.  

Confirmed with @admshao that there is no particular attraction to that behavior.

issue.title: UI: Remove "Return" hotkey for renaming source and scene on macOS

labels.name: Bug Fix
labels.description: Non-breaking change which fixes an issue

repository.name: obs-studio
repository.description: OBS Studio - Free and open source software for live streaming and screen recording

issue.body:
Fixes #3044.  Existing behavior hooks enter to always enter the "EditSceneName" or matching Source entry.

Confirmed with @admshao that this is likely an error and is fine to be removed unless there is UI guidelines that indicate otherwise.

body:
As a macOS use I strongly object to removing this feature entirely as a solution to fixing a bug. 

I'm not sure that the HIG should always be the golden reference as to the only way to do things. 

Ever place you can rename something in macOS Finder being the primary example, but there are others. You can navigate up and down to select a file then press enter to edit and enter to save.

issue.title: Users unable to change scene names

repository.name: obs-studio
repository.description: OBS Studio - Free and open source software for live streaming and screen recording

issue.body:
In the latest version of OBS (or even the previous version), some users can not change the scene names on Mac.
[https://obsproject.com/forum/threads/can-not-rename-scenes-after-they-are-created-obs-24-0-6-mojave-10-14-6-mac.115518/](https://obsproject.com/forum/threads/can-not-rename-scenes-after-they-are-created-obs-24-0-6-mojave-10-14-6-mac.115518/)

## Platform
Operating system and version: macOS Catalina, Version 10.15.6
OBS Studio version: 25.0.8 (64 bit)

## Expected Behavior
User should be able to change the scene name

## Current Behavior
User can not change the scene name. For example, when OBS is fresh installed, user can change the default scene name from "Scene" to "A new Scene Name". Then, user is not able to change the scene name. When entered a new name, hit enter, the name stays the same. If the user adds new scene, none of the scenes can be renamed. The only way to "rename" is via duplication and provide a new name there.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Download and Install OBS
2. Open OBS, skip configuration wizard
3. Change the default scene name, succeed
4. Change the name again, failed
5. Add new scene and change its name, failed
6. Duplicate an arbitrage scene, give it a new name, succeed
7. Try changing the duplicated scene, failed

body:
I think I've traced the issue to this code block
https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/UI/source-tree.cpp#L398-L417

I'm not a mac user, but I can assume the difference between enter and return functionality.
As one condition checks for a LineEditChanged, as saves the data, the other checks for a LineEditCancel, and destorys the edit.
@jp9000 modified this back in d5d8492b, where it used to explicitly use Key values

> I think I've traced the issue to this code block
> https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/UI/source-tree.cpp#L398-L417
> 
> I'm not a mac user, but I can assume the difference between enter and return functionality.
> As one condition checks for a LineEditChanged, as saves the data, the other checks for a LineEditCancel, and destorys the edit.
> @jp9000 modified this back in [d5d8492](https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/commit/d5d8492bb327753ed48d363481e3012e2c358825), where it used to explicitly use Key values

@Scrxtchy 
That seems unlikely since that code is for the Source list, not the Scene list.  This issue is about renaming _scenes_, not sources.  Renaming sources works just fine.  However, when renaming a scene, if you press the rename shortcut key (Return/Enter on macOS, F2 on Windows/Linux), the rename action will restart, discarding any changes you've made to the scene's name.

I've discussed this at length in the Discord's development channel with @mtippett.  The Source list and the Scene list are handled by different classes.  The Source list has a lot of extra code handling edit start, stop, and finished events to prevent this sort of thing occurring there.  The Scene list does not have the same amount of code for it.  As implied by the commit you linked, and as I discussed on Discord, this comes down to the fact that editing is handled by Qt item delegates (editors), and any code preventing the restart of the edit action would have to be linked to the item delegate of the SceneTree, which is a subclassed QListWidget.

@Scrxtchy feel free to connect with me on discord, I'm MeepusMaximus on the OBS discord server.  We can discuss more on that there.  I'm going to be spending more time on it over the next three nights.
